awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Effects of Prescribed Fire on Forest Dynamics and Resource Use
awd_abstract_narration:
This doctoral dissertation research project will analyze how prescribed fire and fire exclusion affect forest dynamics, wildfire risk, and indigenous resource use by the Yurok and Karuk tribes in the Klamath River basin of northwestern California.  This project will enhance knowledge about coupled human-ecological relationships, fire ecology, biogeography, and human behavioral ecology.  By employing the conceptual framework of alternative stable states, this project will provide new insights about the potential influence of intentionally set fires and Native American resource use on ecological community dynamics.  The project will assist the Yurok and Karuk tribes as well as the U.S. Forest Service with their efforts to reinstate prescribed fire as a means to improve access to cultural and subsistence resources and reduce wildfire risk, and it will contribute to assessment of the potential utility of employing prescribed fire in other locales.   The project also will provide new perspectives and data regarding the historical characteristics of fire regimes.  As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this award also will provide support to enable a promising student to establish a strong independent research career.

Small-scale subsistence groups and land managers worldwide intentionally set prescribed fires to improve accessibility to natural resources, enhance resource abundance and distribution, and reduce the spread of wildfire.  After decades of fire exclusion in North America, efforts to revive the use of prescribed burning face several obstacles, such as restrictions, administrative processes, and financial constraints.  Combined with changing climate and land-use regimes, fire exclusion has altered fire regimes, often leading to increases in wildfire size and intensity.  In some parts of the nation, Native American communities are leading prescribed burning efforts because of their cultural connection and reliance on fire-dependent resources.  The restoration of prescribed fire by Yurok and Karuk tribal members provides an opportunity to test hypotheses related to the use of prescribed fire and ecological community dynamics.  Prescribed fires also help meet multiple tribal objectives, including increasing the availability of hazelnut stems for basketry materials; maintaining savannas for deer and elk forage to improve hunting; and reducing wildfire risk.  The doctoral student conducting this project will compare hazelnut stem densities, deer frequencies, and surface fuel loads in burned plots along with matched plots in unburned areas.  He will evaluate the effects these fire regimes may have on resource access by observing the harvesting trips of tribal members as they search for fire-dependent resources, and he will conduct interviews focusing on fire histories at harvesting sites.  He will establish vegetation plots at these harvesting and prescribed fire locations in order to monitor ecological change at each site, and he will analyze aerial photographs and satellite imagery ranging from 1944 to 2016 to compare historical and contemporary savanna characteristics. Transects will be stratified along remnant savanna borders, recent prescribed burns, and adjacent unburned areas to assess species composition under distinctive fire regimes.  To assess effects on wildfire risk, the student will contrast surface fuel loads between prescribed burn and non-burn areas with wildfire models in those ecological communities.

por.por_cntn:
Preceding colonialism, American Indians intentionally set fires to enhance Indigenous resources of cultural and socio-economic significance. However, American Indian removal from their lands, the establishment of National Forests, and the influences of Western forestry severely reduced these ‘cultural burns’ due to policies of fire exclusion. Although public land management agencies have now embraced prescribed burning and other fuel reduction treatments to reduce fire risk and protect property across the United States, the negative effects of fire exclusion persist on a large-scale. Therefore, this project sought to evaluate the social and ecological outcomes associated with fire exclusion and the re-introduction of prescribed cultural fire in Karuk and Yurok Indian territories of northwest California. These Tribes are notable leaders in national efforts to conduct collaborative landscape restoration, and their motivations for cultural burning may serve as a model for other regions.

One of the key resources Karuk and Yurok Tribal members have targeted for cultural burns is California hazelnut (Corylus cornuta var. californica), a deciduous, multi-stemmed, understory shrub that re-sprouts post-disturbance. Tribal members use hazelnut stems for basketry material and the nuts are consumed as food. Baskets composed of hazelnut stems are greatly desired in northwest California Indian communities. One of the baskets in highest demand are baby cradle baskets, as they are a fundamental component of child rearing. These baskets often require ~300 hazelnut stems and sell for approximately $800.

To assess the socio-ecological effects of cultural burning we collaborated with the Karuk and Yurok Tribes, as well as the Cultural Fire Management Council and other community partners to observe and monitor the planning and implementation of 40 prescribed cultural burns, conduct interviews with Indigenous resource users, and observe the stem gathering practices of basketweavers. We also established monitoring plots and collaborated with US Forest Service ecologists to evaluate the effects of burning on the production of California hazelnut basketry stems and nuts, and partnered with the Yurok Tribe Geographic Information Systems program to assess how fire exclusion affected the areal extent of prairies between 1944 and 2016.

In the absence of widespread cultural burning we found that trees have encroached upon prairies that had been important hunting and gathering areas for Yurok communities. Within an approximately 225 km2 area surrounding the Yurok reservation we found that prairie area decreased from 2,209 ha to 501 ha (77.5%) between 1944 and 2016. In the study area, hazelnut shrubs occur at greater densities in forests that have less basal area, or fewer overstory trees, and in forests dominated by hardwood trees like Black oak (Quercus kelioggii) in contrast to coniferous forests. In areas where Tribal members burned three or more times in the past three decades, forests are more likely to have a canopy dominated by hardwood species. In turn, where hazelnut is present in the understory, there is a greater density of these shrubs under hardwood canopies and forests with fewer overstory trees. Within cultural burn areas, hazelnut basketry stems are on average 35-fold greater one growing season (12 – 20 months) after a cultural burn compared to areas that have not been burned in three or more growing seasons. Experiments that employed alternative fire proxy treatments used by basketweavers to promote basketry stem production found that the pile burning of small diameter fuels and litter within hazelnut shrubs, the application of propane torches to hazelnut stems, and the cutting/coppicing of hazelnut stems increased basketry stems 4 – 10 fold compared to untreated shrubs. We found also found that hazel nut production increases with increased solar access. Thus, frequent burning (every 5 – 10 years) and tree thinning are treatments that reduce canopy cover and basal area, and can be used to promote nut productivity in hazelnut groves. Additionally, cultural burns reduced 1-hour fuels (0 - 0.635 cm diameter), 10-hour fuels (0.635 - 2.54 cm diameter), leaf litter, and duff 2 - 7-fold, which decreases potential fire intensities, and allows for improved structure protection.

These findings illustrate that cultural burning has profound effects on forest and savanna ecological dynamics, and on socio-economics. Cultural fire’s positive effects on resource use add an important analytical dimension to the study of fire in North America, and contributes to the broader scholarly study of coupled human and natural systems across multiple disciplines. The outcomes reported from our project can inform land management policies, collaborative fire management partnerships, and the allocation of resources for prescribed fire that influence the social and economic lives of American Indians and other rural communities whose livelihoods rely on forest resources.
